lines.gurmukhi: jYsy imstwn pwn poiK qoiK bwlkih AsQn pwn bwin jnnI imtwveI
lines.transliteration_english: Jaisay Misataan Paan Pokhi Tokhi Baalakahi , Asadan Paan Baani Jananee Mitaavaee ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Just as a mother weans away the child from sucking her breast by feeding him with sweet meats.

lines.gurmukhi: imsrI imlwie jYsy AauKd KvwvY bYdu mITo kir Kwq rogI rogih GtwveI
lines.transliteration_english: Misaree Milaai Jaisay Aoukhad Khavaavai Baidu , Meettho Kari Khaat Rogee Rogahi Ghataavaee ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Just as a physician serves medicine coated with sugar to his patient who readily swallows it, the physician thus cures the patient.

lines.gurmukhi: jYsy jlu sIic sIic Dwnih kiRswn pwlY prpk Bey kit Gr mY lY ilAwveI
lines.transliteration_english: Jaisay Jalu Seechi Seechi Dhaanahi Krisaan Paalai , Parapak Bhaay Kati Ghar Mai Lai Liaavaee ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Just as a farmer irrigates his fields and brings up crops or rice and wheat and when ripe, harvests them and brings it home.

lines.gurmukhi: qYsy gur kwmnw pujwie inhkwm kir inj pd nwmu Dwmu isKY phucwveI ]357]
lines.transliteration_english: Taisay Gur Kaamanaa Pujaai Nihakaam Kari , Nij Pad Naamu Dhaamu Sikhai Pahouchaavaee ?357?

Shabad OS B.translation: So does a True Guru free a Sikh from the worldly affairs and fulfils his desire of consecration. Thus he raises the Sikh high up spiritually through perpetual Naam Simran. (357)
